#selection methods to determine best regressors


```{r}
library(ggplot2)
library(leaps)
library(knitr)
```

#load data

```{r}
library(dplyr)# Load the data
cd <- read.csv(file = "cleanData.csv", header = TRUE, sep = ",", 
                stringsAsFactors = T)

print("ORIGIN DATA")

summary(cd)
```


```{r}
mod = regsubsets(
  churn ~ 
    gender  +
    seniorcitizen +
    dependents +
    partner +
    phoneservice +
    multiplelines +
    internetservice +
    onlinebackup +
    onlinesecurity +
    deviceprotection +
    techsupport +
    streamingtv +
    streamingmovies +
    contract +
    paperlessbilling +
    monthlycharges +
    totalcharges +
    paymentmethod +
    tenure4, 
  data = cd,
  nbest = 10
)
mod.summary = summary(mod)

which.max(mod.summary$adjr2)
which.min(mod.summary$cp)
which.min(mod.summary$bic)

coef(mod, id = 71)

print(mod.summary$adjr2[71])
print(mod.summary$cp[71])
print(mod.summary$bic[71])
```

tied for highest adjr
